events.title: Juneteenth: Emancipation Proclaimed in Texas
events.description: Union General Gordon Granger announced General Order No. 3 in Galveston, Texas, proclaiming the freedom of all slaves in Texas on this day, effectively marking the end of slavery in the United States.
events.significance: Juneteenth became a symbolic day representing African American freedom and the end of slavery, now celebrated as a holiday commemorating emancipation and African American culture.

events.title: Mahatma Gandhi Begins His First Visit to England
events.description: Mahatma Gandhi arrived in England to attend the London Congress of the Indian National Congress and to pursue legal studies, where he developed his philosophy of nonviolent resistance.
events.significance: Gandhi's trip marked the beginning of his wider political activism and leadership in Indiaâ€™s struggle for independence through nonviolent civil disobedience.

events.title: Margaret Thatcher Becomes the First Female Prime Minister to Address the U.S. Congress
events.description: Margaret Thatcher delivered a speech to the United States Congress as the first woman British Prime Minister to do so, strengthening transatlantic relations during the Cold War.
events.significance: The event symbolized strong UK-US relations and highlighted Thatcher's leadership role on the world stage during a critical period.

events.title: Roswell UFO Incident Reported (on June 19 press release)
events.description: The Roswell Army Air Field issued a press release claiming they had recovered a 'flying disc', sparking intense media and public interest in UFO phenomena.
events.significance: This event launched a major ongoing debate and popular interest in UFOs and extraterrestrial life, influencing cultural and scientific discussions for decades.

events.title: Civil Rights Act Signed into Law (Enforcement Begins)
events.description: On June 19, 1964, the Civil Rights Act, signed earlier in the year, began to be enforced, prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.
events.significance: This was a pivotal moment in the American Civil Rights Movement, marking legal progress toward equality and ending segregation.
